context: You receive a message during work hours from someone claiming to be internal IT.
attacker_line:
Hi, this is IT Support.

We detected unusual activity
on your account.

Please confirm your login details.
options: Ask for an official ticket number or contact IT directly
feedback:
Attackers often impersonate IT.
Credentials should never be shared.

Correct.
Always verify requests using trusted channels.
Ignoring avoids danger but reporting is safer.

context: An email arrives claiming your account is about to be disabled.
attacker_line:
Good afternoon.

Your email account will be
suspended within 30 minutes
unless we verify your identity.
options: Reply quickly with the requested information
Click the verification link in the email
Check the sender details and report the message
feedback: Urgency is used to pressure victims into mistakes.
Links are a common phishing technique.

Correct.
Always inspect and report suspicious messages.

context: Someone claims to be from management and requests urgent access.
attacker_line:
Hi, this is Mark from Finance.

I urgently need access
to a document you manage.
The CEO is waiting.
options: Grant access immediately due to urgency
Verify the request through official company channels
Send the document via personal email
feedback: Authority pressure is a common manipulation tactic.

Correct.
Urgency does not override security procedures.
Personal email is not a secure method.

context: You receive a security alert claiming your account is under attack.
attacker_line:
Security Alert!

Multiple failed login attempts
were detected from your account.

Reply ASAP to secure it.
options: Reset your password using the official system
Send your password to stop the attack
feedback: Engaging directly keeps the attacker in control.

Correct.
Always use trusted internal systems.
